climate.description: Generally mild to warm mountain conditions.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Pyr√©n√©es mountains. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional French event. Mountainous Pyr√©n√©es terrain with moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: 66¬∞ South Pyr√©n√©es is a regional event in the Pyr√©n√©es, France‚Äîmountainous terrain with significant elevation. The Pyr√©n√©es mountain scenery is impressive, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. Pyr√©n√©es provides moderate access.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional French gravel race with Pyr√©n√©es mountains. Worth it for French/European cyclists seeking mountain terrain. Not a destination race for international travelers.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in France/Europe and want a Pyr√©n√©es mountain event‚Äîyes, it's solid. If you're international‚Äîthere are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better French events: Wish One Millau. For similar mountain events: other French/Spanish Pyr√©n√©es races.

logistics.food: Pyr√©n√©es has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Pyr√©n√©es mountain terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: On-site only packet pickup with complete file required screams bureaucratic nightmare, especially for international riders. No parking details, no airport information, no lodging strategy‚Äîjust show up and figure it out. Les Angles village location is charming but offers limited infrastructure for race operations.

length.explanation: 110km hits the sweet spot for challenging gravel without becoming an endurance death march. The 74km option provides racing for age group qualifiers while skipping the Formigu√®res-Matemale section. Multiple distance choices prevent the race from being a one-dimensional sufferfest, though none approach epic proportions. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Course features forest trails, rocky paths and mountain roads with singletracks through underbrush. The 20km route includes "a playful single track in the underbrush, technical but smooth" with views of Lake Matemale. Terrain "plays with your nerves" but reads more like mountain fire roads than technical gravel challenges. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 2,134m over 110km delivers Pyrenees climbing with three major ascents including a two-step monster from km 72-87. Racing between 1600-2000m altitude adds respiratory stress to the physical demands. Even the 74km option packs 1,462m of climbing‚Äîthis race earns every meter of vertical. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 60¬∞F and lows of 42¬∞F, with a 47% chance of rain on any given day. September in the Pyrenees offers stable weather windows, though mountain conditions change rapidly at racing altitude of 1600-2000m. Mandatory warm and waterproof clothing requirements suggest organizers expect temperature swings and potential weather exposure during the event. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Racing between 1600-2000m provides noticeable but manageable altitude effects, with routes peaking at 2,400m featuring "rocky trails and forest paths." High enough to feel lung burn on climbs through Scots pine forests around Formigu√®res station, not high enough to require serious acclimatization. Modest altitude compared to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

adventure.explanation: Route explores varied terrain through Capcir, Formigu√®res, and around Lake Calvet with forest trails and rocky paths typical of the southwest Pyrenees. Course climbs "straight into the slope" through forest trail to 1,900m, but 108 checkpoints suggests over-managed adventure rather than true exploration.

prestige.explanation: UCI Gravel World Series qualifier status provides credibility with UCI jerseys and Gran Fondo medals for qualifiers. Post-race prize-giving ceremony rewards top 3 overall plus category winners, but this remains a baby race with no legendary winners or established gravel community recognition.

race_quality.explanation: Well-stocked refreshment stations with zero waste operation and comprehensive safety coverage throughout 108 checkpoints shows organizational competence. Medical assistance and signage included, though on-site only packet pickup and 7 PM same-day cutoff creates logistical stress for participants.

experience.explanation: Post-race prize ceremony at 7 PM same day with music evening invitation creates proper celebration atmosphere. Welcome bags for participants and 30% discounts on local activities like Lou Bac Mountain and Angl√©o Baln√©o add value to the village finish experience in Les Angles.

community.explanation: Regional French cycling culture runs deep, and the race builds on an established road event with local support. Village start/finish in Les Angles creates intimate atmosphere, and the range of distances (20km to 110km) suggests inclusive community building.

field_depth.explanation: UCI qualifier status attracts riders chasing World Championship spots with separate age-group qualification categories (men 60+/women 50+ for 74km option). Time gates enforce competitive standards by stopping riders who miss cutoffs, though field size and notable participants remain unknown. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: ‚Ç¨80 for 110km includes timing, aid stations, medal, welcome bag, and 30% discounts on local activities like cable cars and spa access. That's reasonable for European gravel racing, especially with the Pyrenees location. Multiple distance options provide entry points, though the shortest costs ‚Ç¨20 for essentially a neighborhood loop.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs ‚Ç¨60-100. Les Angles mountain resort location means paying peak season rates with limited lodging options. Mandatory equipment includes hard helmet, repair kit, and weather-appropriate clothing, adding gear costs. The 30% local activity discount helps slightly but you're paying Pyrenees resort pricing. Higher total cost than Badlands.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: TRANSPYRENEES | bikepacking 1000 km across the Pyrenees
videos.description:
"This is a story of two friends, going on their first adventure together. Bikepacking across the Pyrenees". Two weeks, thousand kilometres, and nearly 25 thousands meters to climb. From the Mediterranean sea to the Atlantic ocean, we cycled across the Pyrenees, and attacked many boulangeries. 

My fourth crossing of the Pyrenees, and something tells me it definitely wasn't the last one :-)

// MY GEAR // 
Bike: ROSE Backroad, SRAM Force & Eagle transmission
Kit & glasses: Straede cycling apparel
Bags: RESTRAP
Bottles: KEEGO (Denisa15 for 15% off)
Tires: Hutchinson Tundra 45 mm
Snacks: YANAA
Tent: Big Agnes Fly Creek
Sleeping pad: Big Agnes Rapid SL
Sleeping bag: Patizon G800
Camera: Fujifilm XS10 & iPhone14 pro

*Some of the gear was gifted // brand ambassador // ad due to brand mentioning

// Instagram // 
Denisa https://instagram.com/denixxaa
Martina https://www.instagram.com/martinawankova

See you at the next one :)

#bikepacking #pyrenees #adventure #cycling #cyclingpyrenees #bikepackingpyrenees #gravel #traveldocumentary #bikepackingdocumentary
videos.transcript:
This is a story of two friends going on
their first adventure together.
Always snacking and yapping about
everything and nothing.
Brushing teeth. Well, fine, not always.
Making new friends.
and somewhere between it all, riding
bikes.
Even out there in the wild, they
couldn't run away from doing laundry and
maintenance.
But luckily, they did manage to run away
from horses.
Well, you know, just all the normal
stuff that one does when crossing the
Bernies.
Every good story begins somewhere. And
our began in Catalonia.
It was Friday at 400 p.m. that we set
off to cross the Pyrenees.
2 weeks, 1,00 kilome and nearly 25,000 m
of elevation gain.
>> And I feel like I'm in jail
and
>> I asked Martina how she enjoys the
pennies so far.
And just like that, the road became our
home and the panny's are playground.
>> In the next two weeks, we will share
everything together from unforgettable
roads to toilets. So, we will for sure
learn a lot.
We didn't know it at the time, but it
turns out that we cannot really get sick
of each other, no matter how hard we
try.
>> Come on down for the weekend.
didn't know if I could spare the
>> Well, it's no longer dry and hot like it
was by the sea and I woke up with a sore
throat. So, we made a little trip to the
pharmacy.
I lost count how many times we had to
put on and off our rain jackets. But
just like the cows, we continued on our
way and we didn't really mind the rain.
Well, not until the thunderstorm caught
us on top of a mountain and suddenly the
heatwave of day one didn't seem so bad
anymore.
>> Soaked to the bones, we found shelter in
a barn and a good company.
The sun came back eventually, but we
still chose to stay in a hotel that
night. A good call because the storm
came back even stronger and kept us
awake for a good part of the night.
But at least this time we had cozy
blankets and we were dry.
Slowly but surely, we were moving away
from the Mediterranean Sea and a little
closer to the Atlantic.
The pies are very diverse and they
change every day.
We decided to take a shortcut,
which of course turned into a rough
hiker bike.
And as if having the flu wasn't enough,
I managed to twist my ankle pretty bad.
Well, it's one way of training my
endurance.
At the end of the day, we pitched our
tent near Mountain Refuge at a spot
dedicated to campers, but also to
horses.
What at first felt like a dream
eventually turned into a nightmare. The
horses got a bit too curious and started
examinating our equipment and rubbing
their cute butts against marking a
single bar. At 1:00 a.m. we were woken
up by a horse knocking on our front
door, kicking our front door.
Unfortunately, we didn't have any place
for him in the tent. And well, between
my coughing and the horses galloping
next to our heads, we didn't really get
much sleep. So big breakfast was a must
and slow morning inevitable.
Eventually we said goodbye to our new
friends and terrorists by night and
begin cycling to Andura.
We decided to take a rest day in Andura.
You have forsen
all the love you ten sleeping on a razor
left so far. Your body's aching. Every
bone is breaking. Nothing seems to shake
it. It just keeps holding on.
Anyway, apologies for all this lovely
content, but my runny nose was such a
big part of our adventure. Perhaps it's
official soundtrack, so it didn't
actually feel right to not include it.
But as it turns out, blowing my nose on
camera is really, really hard.
For once, we managed to get up quite
early. We enjoyed a breakfast buffet,
stole some sandwiches for the road, and
we started climbing up to Port Caboose,
which was our door back to Spain. Every
man desires
everyone.
No one left to harm.
For the past 6 days, I've been stealing
toilet paper in cafes around. And let me
tell you, some are better than others.
Both a paper and a coffee.
There is no
love.
>> We are back in the line of horses and
cows.
>> One must be really careful in the
descent because you never know when
there's a horse standing in your way.
Heat
up
here.
It's already been a long day and it
wasn't over yet. We were discussing
whether to stay in the valley or push
for another big climb.
>> Time flies differently in the Perennies.
One day can feel like many, but at the
same time, the days are timeless.
We got to the caban in the night, so we
didn't really know where we are
sleeping. It was another very stormy
night. What a surprise to wake up to
this view,
>> which I couldn't appreciate fully until
I had my contacts on and my morning cup
of coffee.
What else?
It didn't take long until our neighbors
came to say hi.
>> Probably wondering who are those
twolegged creatures peeing on the same
spot as them.
We were hanging out for a couple of
hours, but since we had no more food, we
had to leave at some point.
It was a quiet ride. Short but intense.
We were really hungry. A bit angry.
Luckily, never at each other. So, we
just kept being angry together.
This was a spectacular day. Big day.
But when the brain has so much beauty to
process it all the time, the kilometers
pass quite fast.
Even I felt better. still coughing,
still stealing toilet paper, but some of
my energy finally came back and I was
able to be on the road again.
There are a lot of ups and downs,
sometimes at different times for each. I
was feeling pretty great that day, but
Martin, on the other hand, was feeling a
bit stressed. We see the same places,
but we don't always experience them in
the same way.
So we can try to lift each other up and
meet somewhere in the middle.
What Martina told me got stuck in my
mind. In a way, I suffer a lot, but when
it's for something you love, it doesn't
really hurt.
The last climb of the day took us to
France, where we would stay for the rest
of the trip.
Then we ate delicious Vietnamese food
and slept at a place with a washing
machine. Priceless.
We knew this part would be very
different.
Big road climbs on the menu with
legendary tour of France names like
perisut
or obvisk.
The climbs we got the views on the
sometimes. For 2 days we were riding in
the thick fog. Even in my memory these
days blur into one big cloud.
What I do remember is that we ate really
good.
The clouds added a sense of mystery and
surprise. Even though it was wet and
cold, it was truly spectacular.
There's something special about climbing
all day in the gray and then suddenly
breaking through, discovering what's
been hiding inside the clouds.
like lamas for example.
Well, the best things in life don't come
easy, but do we ever regret the effort?
away from the first nation
for Jesus Christ.
Get out my phone.
I don't know.
We didn't leave our camp spot until 12.
And by that time, our soul was wellfed,
but our stomachs were feeling
particularly empty.
crunchy
seafood bey.
Yeah.
>> Okay.
Every night.
It was really hard to leave the bed in
the morning, but a smell of coffee
coming on from the breakfast room of our
BNB eventually helped us out of the trap
of comfort.
The breakfast was all sugar, perfect for
me, not so great for Martina, who
prefers salty. Lucky for her, it was
very hot these days, and we would start
climbing the second we go out of the
door. So, she would get salty in no
time.
And you
count the waves in every sailboat.
Feel the breeze, the warm and moist.
Hear the sound. Just one big old
coming from the ocean.
ready.

warm and moist.
You sound just one little
We arrived to the Bas country. A place I
once called home. And some part of me
still feels at home here. I don't know
what's up with this place, but to me,

The last time I'm doing laundry in the
sink. I hate it, but when it's the last

about it. about drying my underwear on

Ready

>> As we are getting closer to the end,

We take more time. We drink more beers.
Half waiting for the end and half

>> For sure we are tired and we kind of

Can we keep this feeling? The one that
only life on the road awakened for a few

We are dodging sheep on the climbs and

It's hot.
The storm is coming
and inevitably so is the end.
I can't
find

>> It feels like a lifetime, but actually

videos.title: PYRENEES FRANCE: The MOST FAMOUS mountain passes in the FRENCH PYRENEES
videos.description:
From west to east over the most famous mountain passes of the Pyrenees in France: Join a motorcycle ride to Col du Tourmalet, Col d'Aubisque and Col de Peyresourde on the french part of the Pyrenees mountain range. 

Ride a motorcycle in the Spanish-French mountains of the Pyrenees, they said. It will be amazing they said. There will be fantastic views, they said. 
So I rode to the Pyrenees. Not only once, not twice, but for the third time. And this time, my journey to the Pyrenees was the most challenging so far. Follow my ride over high mountain passes in dense fog. 

00:00 Introduction Pyrenees
01:01 Ride from Spain to the Pyrenees
02:32 The gateway to the Pyrenees - the town Pau
03:21 Enter the Pyrenees at Lunchon and have Lunch at Chez Trey in B√©ost
05:20 Visit the scenic town Eaux-Bonnes
06:10 Ride to the ski resort Gourette
07:04 Approach Col d'Aubisque and take a picture with its enormous bicycles
10:18 Ride through the village Argel√®s-Gazost on the way to the next mountain pass of the Pyrenees
10:50 Col du Tourmalet - the most famous mountain pass of the Pyrenees
13:17 Arreau and  Col de Peyresourde
13:40 Bagn√®res-de-Luchon and its Hot Springs and thermes

// DESTINATION HOME: Join a motorcycle journey to the best places in Europe - from Switzerland to France, Spain, Andorra and Italy.

// Support my journey and help me to stay independent!
- BECOME A PATREON (and be always the first to know about my new journeys): https://www.patreon.com/got2go
- BUY ME A TANK OF FUEL: https://www.buymeacoffee.com/got2go

// NEW EPISODE OUT EVERY THURSDAY 19.30 CET

// Time of the journey: JULY-AUGUST 2021

// My book GOT2GO about my solo motorcycle trip around the world is OUT NOW!
Order the paperback book on Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B095556HPG
Order the ebook for kindle: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B092MYKGLF
Or access the book over the Amazon page of your country by searching for "Got2Go" "Lea Rieck"

// Riding my Yamaha T√©n√©r√© 700 called FOX. Bought the motorcycle myself in 2019.
Watch the review here: https://youtu.be/S7yybRaVUwc

//Equipment & Gear:
- Touratech Companero Summer Jacket & Pants (given to me by Touratech after my old suit got stolen on the ship from westafrica)
- BMW GS Gloves (self bought)
- Alpinestar Toucan Boots (self bought)
- Klim Krios Pro Helmet (self bought)
- Leatt Neckbrace  (given to me by Leatt as my self-bought neckbrace was still in Africa)

Watch the review for my helmets here:
https://youtu.be/hOqLnqAHdAQ

//Filmed with:
Drone: DJI Mavic 2 Zoom
Camera: Sony Alpha A7 rIII
2 x Go Pro Hero 8

range of the Pyrenees
because from here, the roads

one of the most important valleys
across the Pyrenees-Atlantiques
department.
The town center in Eaux-Bonnes

On a raised platform
